title: New York Times headlines 1960
content:
Hello everybody. I have to recreate the entire front page of The New York Times from 1960 and I'm wondering if anyone here might know what they used to typeset the following:

– the main headlines  
– the date & price etc in the masthead  
– subheadings  
– main body copy

Thank you for any advice!

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725060756im_/http:/typophile.com/files/tmp1A156_3989.jpg)
author: Rhiannon

comments.content: The main headlines are all versions of Cheltenham.

As for the nameplate -- the part that looks similar to Old English -- this was hand-drawn. [http://www.typophile.com/node/19590](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725060756/http:/www.typophile.com/node/19590 "http://www.typophile.com/node/19590") English Towne is a very rough approximation. In 1967 the New York Tunes adopted "Imperial" as the running text font. I don't know what it used before then.  
Don

Thank you! Both very useful.

Do you have any ideas about what the tall san-serif subhead font might be? I was thinking maybe Akzidenz, but it seems a bit rounder-edged or something?

Sorry for lack of technical terminology

Possibly Franklin Gothic Extra Cond [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/franklin-gothic/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140725060756/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/franklin-gothic/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/franklin-gothic/")  
Don
